Description: A brief Problem Statement of the requirement
Description of the client's current methods for inspection.
Specific issues or challenges faced with the current inspection methods.
Improvements the client wishes to achieve with the new system.
The client's budget for the system to tailor a cost-effective solution.
Metrics to measure the success of the vision system.
Client's criteria for ROI on the vision system.
Anticipated future requirements or expansions.
How the vision system needs to integrate with current business systems.
Any regulatory or industry compliance requirements.
Any environmental goals or standards to adhere to.
Unique Name or identifier for the product that needs to be inspected.
Brief overview of the product, its use, and key features.
Option for users to upload images of the product for visual reference.
Brief description of why the product needs inspection (e.g., quality control, compliance, etc.).
Min and Max Dimensions of the product.
Description of where and how the product is used.
Importance and Role of the inspection process in its usage context.
Unique identifiers for each variant.
Descriptions highlighting differences between variants.
Minimum and maximum dimensions for all variants.
Notable features unique to certain variants.
Option to upload images for
Annual/Monthly Production Voume (total as well as Variant wise breakup)
Option to upload a 3D model of the product.
How products are transported to the inspection area.
Description of how parts are loaded into the inspection system.
Speed at which products are handled or moved.
Specifies whether the part is moving or stationary during the inspection process.
How rejected (Not Good) components are managed and what action should be taken.
What happens when a part is passed by the vision system.
How the system manages changes between different product variants.
Option to upload or describe mechanical drawings related to material handling.
Visual reference of the current material handling setup.
List all different variants in the scope of this inspection and mention any out-of-scope variants.
Describe cycle time and inspection speed.
Inputs from external systems interfaced with the vision system.
Outputs like PNP, TTL, EthernetIP, and interfacing details.
What happens in scenarios of failed, unknown, or error detections.
Open text for any other material handling requirements.
Specific conditions required for handling, like temperature control or fragility considerations.
List of specific standards or specifications the system must comply with.
Specifies the material standards required for the components.
List of actions the operator is allowed to perform.
Actions the operator is not allowed to perform.
How variant information is communicated to the vision system.
Any operator alerts or notifications.
Preferred languages for the interface.
Details on the integration with external databases for data management.
Information on integration with Enterprise Resource Planning systems.
Parameters for image data backup.
Preferred backup storage solution.
Result feedback to be communicated to the production line .
Information on the physical space needed for the system.
What kind of internet connectivity can be provided for remote training and testing and later for troubleshooting
Details about power supply and network connectivity requirements.
Whether the customer can provide sufficient sample products for training the system as well as for testing and system calibration.
Information about the level of on-site support and training required for the client.
Specific environmental factors where the system will be deployed, such as temperature, humidity, lighting, and contaminants.
Technical expertise and training requirements of the end-users of the system.
Industry-specific regulations or standards the system must comply with.
Maintenance needs, expected system lifespan, and support requirements.
Specific performance metrics expected from the system and how success is defined.
Potential risks or challenges in implementing the system for proactive planning.
Specific criteria that the vision system must meet for acceptance.
The duration of the testing phase before final acceptance.
Number of samples to be tested during the acceptance phase.
Defined limits for what constitutes a failure during testing.
Details on reporting format and frequency during the trial period.
Requirement for on-site testing as part of the acceptance process.
Schedule and criteria for reviewing the system's performance post-implementation.
Confirmation that user training has been successfully completed.
Testing the system's integration with existing processes and equipment.
Process for formally accepting the system, including any necessary documentation or approvals.
